message_1:
Here's an example question based on modal logic:

Consider a modal language with only two possible atomic propositions, p and q. Let K be a knowledge operator, so that Kp denotes "it is known that p." Write down a formula to express the following sentence: 

"It is not the case that p is known and q is not known."

Solution: 

¬(Kp ∧ ¬Kq)
message_2: You have correctly written the formula to express the given sentence in modal logic. The formula ¬(Kp ∧ ¬Kq) represents "It is not the case that p is known and q is not known."
